DataElement.preferredName: Surgical Procedure Lumpectomy Excisional Biopsy Performed Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Yes/No/Don't know indicator to signify whether an excisional biopsy or lumpectomy was performed

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Surgical Procedure Lumpectomy Excisional Biopsy Performed
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to lumpectomy, the removal of a cancer as well as some of the breast tissue around the tumor and the lining over the chest muscles below the tumor, or excisional biopsy, a surgical procedure in which an entire lump or suspicious area is removed for diagnosis, sed for operative procedures on organs, as the surgical procedure being performed.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Used for operative procedures on organs, regions, or tissues in the treatment of diseases, including tissue section by lasers. It excludes transplantation, for which "transplantation" is used.

Concepts.definition: A diagnostic or treatment procedure performed by manual and/or instrumental means, often involving an incision and the removal or replacement of a diseased organ or tissue; of or relating to or involving or used in surgery or requiring or amenable to treatment by surgery.

Property.preferredDefinition: The removal of a cancer as well as some of the breast tissue around the tumor and the lining over the chest muscles below the tumor. Usually some of the lymph nodes under the arm are also taken out.  Also called segmental mastectomy.:(ek-SI-zhun-al BY-op-see) A surgical procedure in which an entire lump or suspicious area is removed for diagnosis. The tissue is then examined under a microscope.:Performed; carried out.

Concepts.definition: The surgical removal of a discrete mass.
A surgical procedure in which an entire lesion is removed for microscopic examination.
Executed and carried through to completion.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: actions or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process (NCI).

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The affirmative response to a question or activity._The non-affirmative response to a question._The answer is not known by the person answering._An event, entity or condition that typically characterizes a prescribed environment or situation and determines or aids in determining whether certain stated circumstances exist or criteria are satisfied.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The answer is not known by the person answering.

Concepts.definition: The answer is not known by the person answering.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The non-affirmative response to a question.

Concepts.definition: The non-affirmative response to a question.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The affirmative response to a question or activity.

Concepts.definition: The affirmative response to a question.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the results of evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: The affirmative response to a question or activity.:The non-affirmative response to a question.:The answer is not known by the person answering.:An event, entity or condition that typically characterizes a prescribed environment or situation and determines or aids in determining whether certain stated circumstances exist or criteria are satisfied.

Concepts.definition: The affirmative response to a question.
The non-affirmative response to a question.
The answer is not known by the person answering.

An event, entity or condition that typically characterizes a prescribed environment or situation and determines or aids in determining whether certain stated circumstances exist or criteria are satisfied.

ReferenceDocuments.name: Have you ever had a surgical
ReferenceDocuments.description: Have you ever had a surgical breast biopsy, which is the removal of breast tissue by surgery for the purpose of making a diagnosis?

ReferenceDocuments.name: lumpectomy
ReferenceDocuments.description: Have you ever had a surgical procedure to have a breast lump or tumor removed (lumpectomy)?
